section.title: Tutorial 2: Navigating object details pages
section.para: This tutorial will guide you through the structure of the object details pages and how to navigate them. The object details page for the 'bib' gene will be used as an example. All object details pages have the same basic structure and so this example can be extended to other items in the database.

Enter the gene symbol 'bib' into the Quick Search box on the FlyMine home page. See Tutorial 1 for more information. The query returns just one result so you are taken directly to a summary page for the gene:

The top left shows summary information for this gene - identifier, name and chromosome coordinates. Use the '+' boxes next to 'proteins', 'synonyms', etc. to open inline tables with more details. The 'FASTA' buttons retrieve sequences for any feature they appear next to.

listitem.para: A link to the FlyBase gene report.
A GBrowse image for the area surrounding this gene. Clicking on the image takes you to the GBrowse genome viewer. Clicking on any feature in GBrowse will take you to a summary page in FlyMine.
'bib' has results from the Arbeitman et al 2002 time course microarray experiment. The graph shows Log 2 Ratio gene expression for 67 samples.

section.para: Scroll down the page to see 'Other details by aspect':

This section has more detailed information about this gene divided into 'aspects'. The aspects correspond to categories of data shown on the FlyMine home page. Look at the Genomics aspect. Entries in green show fields directly related to this gene. Use '+' boxes to open summary tables. For example, opening 'overlappingFeatures' will summarise genome annotation that overlaps the chromosome coordinates of this gene.
Entries in black text allow you to see the results of predefined queries run for this gene ('templates'). Those shown in light grey did not return any results.
[details...] links take you to summary pages for related database entries. Scroll back up to the top of the page and click the [details...] link next to 'proteins':
This page presents more information about the 'BIB_DROME' protein. The trail at the top keeps track of [details...] links you have followed.
